reviewText:
Early Access Review

World war 2 first person shooter game with progression and a 'Strategic Multiplayer Campaign'.

If that sounds interesting, I'm sorry.

Given that this is a beta/early access game, it's possible it could improve. However one of the biggest issues is poor hit registration. The game can be unbalanced and/or poorly designed but none of that really matters if the gun play is good.

Heroes & Generals gun play is flat out awful. I've played a lot of shooters over the years and this is one of a handful of games I would say this about. The inconsistency at which this game operates is ridiculous. I've gotten more kills in this game spraying in the general direction of my opponents, then I've ever gotten carefully aiming.

At first I thought this was just the common f2p tactic of starting you off with a lackluster gun in an attempt to coerce a purchase from you. Luckily you can pick up other player's modded out weapons and find out they are just as bad.

I can not recommend playing this to anyone without serious self-esteem issues who feel like they don't deserve a better game. Unless you are like me and have a friend that loves the 'challenge' of this game.

In which case I would recommend having a good sense of humor so you can properly enjoy dying in one hit from full health to a leg shot or having your motor cycle flip over a fence into a group of eight, dismounting killing them all then dying to a friendly grenade. Or getting into a friendly bullet filled ADADAD dance contest with the enemy team sadly cut three hours short by a jealous recon.

Basically: 4/10 wouldn't queue up

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has  ALOT of pottential. It has its flaws and it has its  good sides.

The good

- It is a really fun game to play with friends.
- Maybe the best ww2 fps in a long while. ( it is a shame there arent that many of those)
- The mix of vehicles in the game ( Could need some balancing but not that much)
- The ability to modify your guns the way you want.
-  Shooting in the game in general is just fabulous, u actually have to think abit where you shoot and when you shoot. not just spray mindlesly like in normal fps games where the bullets go exactly there where you aim.
- You dont unlock everthing in the game the instant you start it, you actually need to play it to get the guns you want. ( The minus side of the thing is you can buy them with real money but hey, the devs need to get their money somehow from this awesome game)

The bad.

- It has a lot of bugs. ALOT
- There is abit too much server downtime.
- The guns between allied and axis are bit too unbalanced
- There should be a tank limit in the game. ( Too many people just wanna go to tank for easy frags because no1 bothers to destroy them when its really easy)
- The matchmaking should be more reasonable with the squads there are on each side. There is no point when the other side has 20 tank squads and other one has just infantry.
-  The squad system is really bad. You cant play with your friends if they want to  be a paratrooper / tankman / recon / pilot unless you make a new infantry character.
- The matchmaking should not put Rank 14 vs Rank 1. There is just no point this should be balanced somehow.
- The chat doesnt work, atleast not for me.
- The maps repeat themselfs alot.. Hoping there will be alot of new maps when this things gets actually released.
- Too many people leave the game too early and then you are just stuck in a deploy queue, which is stupid that you get punished for the other team meambers for leaving. This should be changed somehow. A big penalty for leaving  or a big reward for playing the game to the end.
-  The generals side of the game is just pointles. Delete that and focus your time on the actual game and make it work better
- The game fps is way too low for how it looks.
- The point system is abit stupid. Specially the capture when only the first one gets the 28 poins and others 13. This should be the same for everyone. Or the points come from the time spent on capturing.  You should get alot of more points when destroying tanks with bazookas / nades.  The points from headshots should be abit more. Tho this is not nessesary.
- Community whining that it is Pay to win, when it clearly is not.

I would recommend this game for everyone who likes WW2 games and more of an simulator fps than an arcade fps.

These were just a few things that popped in to my head while writing this review. If you have some toughts or ideas you would want to share. just write them in to the comments. This is how i think about the game. It has a very good future if the dev team just keeps working on it and keeps making it better and better. Hoping they get the bugs and server side things cleared and start making new content to this game !

There could be alot of typing errors in this review sorry for that.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not worth time for a couple reasons!
Firstly, they've utilized a pay to win system. This causes a lot of balance issues. Paying players will have access to much of the game, while normal players will face an unreasonable grind before unlocking AND buying (with silver currency) the game content.
Secondly, the gameplay dazzles no one as it is mostly like many existing shooters. Don't be fooled by the brushed up screenshots or trailers/videos. The gameplay becomes dreadful as you realize what is going on and how much of a pointless grind this game is. The graphics do not help much either (once again, do not be fooled by brushed up screenshots, the game doesn't pack much as it is a relatively small game). As of reviewing, which is early access, the servers are shaky, which makes the gameplay even worse (might be better after official launch).

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Played a whole lot of this game and I have to say its not very good.

The basic mechanics of the game are solid enough. Pretty standard fps controls. Vehichles feel alright for the most part and so does shooting. Couldn't tell you about planes because in spite of spending 175 hrs on the game I have not unlocked the ability to fly them since I don't have infinite money. The main issue with the game is the simply horrible F2P model that makes the game such a chore to play.

In spite of the near infinite amount of unlockables across all the factions the game has a terrible system for earning in game currency. It is very much a pay 2 win game. Takes ages to unlock most things between the xp requirments to unlock items and the currency cost. There are counteless ways to spend real money to subvert these time constraints including buying better soldiers, buying the weapons/items or buying veterancy status which basically doubles your rate of obtaining xp and money. Most of the costs for anything are really high. Don't expect to unlcok most items without playing countless games per item. Worst of all there is no ability to sell items to get some of your in game money back. Couple this with the fact that you can't test items before buying them unless you are lucky enough to find one on the battlefield this makes for a terrible system.

TLDR don't play this game unless you enjoy wasting money or literally all you want to do is shoot people with the starter rifles.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

This starts out as a great game.  Good graphics, good movement mechanics.  Things look and sound like they should and there is a terrific amount of area on a map to explore as well as a variety of ways to develop your heroes.  But then things start going south rapidly.

First there is the premium currency trap.  You earn credits in the game based on how long you are playing.  Not how well you do in a given match, not for doing things, just for time in a match.  These credits must later be spent on maintaining your soldier's gear or you can't use them.  You also have to maintain any weapon upgrades.  You also have to maintain any vehicles you used, if any, as well as their upgrades and of course ammunition.  Once all that is done, if you have any credits left over, then you can buy things that your XP has unlocked.

But Wait!  All this can be avoided if you just open up your wallet and buy premium currency.   Otherwise you are stuck grinding up credits while using the basic gear.  Not because you don't have better but because you can't afford to use better.


Secondly, there are ways to set things up so the following will happen.  Player A and Player B round a corner and run into each other.  Player A has an automatic weapon and reacting first immediately fires a burst into the body of Player B.  Player B has a single shot, non-sniper rifle and fires back, hitting Player A in a limb and killing him instantly.  Player B carries on, only lightly damaged by the automatic weapons fire he took.  Player B wins the encounter, not due to superior skill, but rather due to superior use of money to maximize the games badge and perk system.

Thirdly, there is the poor balance of the strength of sides in battle formats.  An example:  Side A is defending a point against Side B.  Side B must cross an obstacle and open ground to reach their objectives.   Side A will have fortified positions, pillboxes, AA guns, machine gun nests and armor.  Side B gets....infantry, bicycles, jeeps and if very, very lucky, an apc.  What usually happens is that Side B rushes forward in an attempt to seize positions before Side A can mobilize from spawn.  If they succeed, well and good.  Side B has a fighting chance.  But what usually happens is the Side B gets driven back as Side A rolls over the 'attacker' with armor and wins by capping Side b's spawn points in an irresistable tide.



H and G could have become a truly, truly great game loved by thousands if not millions.  But the continuous repetition of the above examples and things like them drove people away from what could have been a legendary franchise.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI started playing this game a while ago... and so far, the updates are only killing it more and more each time. The devs do not understand how to balance power between factions, and how to give each army advantages/disadvantages that make the game enjoyable. They have obviously been in a beta state for too long, but that is besides the point. I have purchased the veteran upgrades multiple times, for months at a time, and that seems to be the only way to get an edge on the combat field. People who don't pay to play are not going to get very far. At this point, the game is so unenjoyable that even the grind isn't worth it anymore. Please, take it from me; someone who has spent probably a hundred or more dollars to play a free game. Don't waste your time or money on this game. I admit, it is one of the more developed WWII games, but really. It isn't worth it. I regret all the time I have spent playing this game. New updates only make factions more and more unbalanced. I have played as all three factions, but primarily the Americans; with a soldier in each group (tanker, paratrooper, recon, pilot). The teams are all so under/overbalanced depending on the side, its just not fun anymore. Devs, please get your ♥♥♥♥ together and stop begging people for money to play a game that you promised would be free.

This starts out as a great game.  Good graphics, good movement mechanics.  Things look and sound like they should and there is a terrific amount of area on a map to explore as well as a variety of ways to develop your heroes.  But then things start going south rapidly.

First there is the premium currency trap.  You earn credits in the game based on how long you are playing.  Not how well you do in a given match, not for doing things, just for time in a match.  These credits must later be spent on maintaining your soldier's gear or you can't use them.  You also have to maintain any weapon upgrades.  You also have to maintain any vehicles you used, if any, as well as their upgrades and of course ammunition.  Once all that is done, if you have any credits left over, then you can buy things that your XP has unlocked.

But Wait!  All this can be avoided if you just open up your wallet and buy premium currency.   Otherwise you are stuck grinding up credits while using the basic gear.  Not because you don't have better but because you can't afford to use better.


Secondly, there are ways to set things up so the following will happen.  Player A and Player B round a corner and run into each other.  Player A has an automatic weapon and reacting first immediately fires a burst into the body of Player B.  Player B has a single shot, non-sniper rifle and fires back, hitting Player A in a limb and killing him instantly.  Player B carries on, only lightly damaged by the automatic weapons fire he took.  Player B wins the encounter, not due to superior skill, but rather due to superior use of money to maximize the games badge and perk system.

Thirdly, there is the poor balance of the strength of sides in battle formats.  An example:  Side A is defending a point against Side B.  Side B must cross an obstacle and open ground to reach their objectives.   Side A will have fortified positions, pillboxes, AA guns, machine gun nests and armor.  Side B gets....infantry, bicycles, jeeps and if very, very lucky, an apc.  What usually happens is that Side B rushes forward in an attempt to seize positions before Side A can mobilize from spawn.  If they succeed, well and good.  Side B has a fighting chance.  But what usually happens is the Side B gets driven back as Side A rolls over the 'attacker' with armor and wins by capping Side b's spawn points in an irresistable tide.



H and G could have become a truly, truly great game loved by thousands if not millions.  But the continuous repetition of the above examples and things like them drove people away from what could have been a legendary franchise.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is a combination of a fast paced game and a slow paced game. Sometimes when you're capturing a city you could engage with enemy soldiers in short range, but sometimes when defending or just engaging a city you could see an enemy from far and you take your time to make a clean headshot or just wait for the perfect moment to shoot.

Why i love this is game is bc you control how you want to play it. Do you like fast paced games, go ahead take a submachine gun and blast the hell out of ppl in the middle of action while capturing or defending. Do you like slow paced games (like me) lie down in the woods and wait till someone goes and captures your city and take him out. Or lie in the forest and help your fellow teammates capturing the city by taking out incoming enemies.

Also a great thing is that there are tanks, cars, bikes, planes (bombers and fighters), paratroopers, etc. It's just epic to see that your teammate drops a bomb on an enemy tank that is trying to kill you. Or just seeing a friendly tank fighting with an enemy tank and see paratroopersd descending from the sky. I myself haven't played as one of them. I'm still waiting to become recon and buy a sniper rifle to take those guys out from a distance.

It's kinda pay to win, but if you rank up you get more money with battles, so if you have patience you can achieve a new weapon, vehicle and some modifications in 10 hours of playing.

It is F2P, just check it out!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Before rating down my review just because it has a 'pros' section on a game that has bad reputation and you completely disagree with me & hate this game, read the reason on part 4 first. I am criticizing this game objectively without bias, so don't expect me to only bash the game with bad reviews like other popular reviews to satisfy your hatred of the game. I am completely aware this game has a bad reputation on the community due various reasons. So please, read first, rate later. My review consists of:
1. Pros
2. Cons
3. TL;DR
4. Pay to Win explanation; why so many negative reviews, including mine?

1. Pros
+ Gameplay is fun. It's the only good WW2 MMOFPS out there with large player base and this kind of gameplay. Would've been better if they are using PlanetSide 2's style, though. But maybe it's protected with copyright.
+ Moderate scale of battle. Unlike most other 5v5 MMOFPS, Heroes and Generals has a 18v18 map
+ Good graphics, but not great.
+ Good shooting system. Snipers will be affected by gravity (but not wind) and they will have to adjust their scope accordingly. Weapons that appears to be blocked by certain object won't be able to hit the target just because the crosshair is on the target. And last but not least, unlike CoD, recoil exists here. In general, shooting system is challenging (especially long range shooting), but the difficulty does not overwhelm the fun.
+ Various tanks & other land vehicles, planes, even bicycles
+ Haven't tried the 'Generals' side where you get to deploy troops to win the war, but I heard people said it's pretty good
+ Weapon choice is limited, but adequate. You won't easily purchase any good weapons without using the bad ones first since there are prerequisite to fulfill before purchasing one. So progress is needed to achieve good weaponry.
+ Soldier classes, ranks, and other visual progress bar technique to keep you addicted
+ Three out of 5 WW2 major military power is here (Russia, US, Nazi)
+ Teamwork heavily determine the outcome of the battle. Individual skills only affect snipers.
+ Game is being updated frequently with the devs actively streaming on twitch.

2. Cons
- Reloading animation doesn't make sense. After 2 shots with my Kar98k, the reloading animation shows me putting in 5 bullets. Bullet count always resets to zero when you reload.
- Clunky & crude animations, makes close quarter combat very awkward
- One type of plane. No bombers, which is weird. Dive bombers played a big role in WW2.
- Game stays in Early Alpha for a very long time. Showing that the updates are quite insignificant and devs are only trying to increase the pay-to-win range.
- No Japanese & British? All major military powers in WW2 would be complete if they add the Japs & the British, maybe they're still working on it (French was also a major one in Allied Forces but they surrendered early)
- Pay to Win system is very blatant and annoying, complete expalantion on part 4
- Terrain texture is crude, trees and grass are like from the early 2000s games.
- Lack of objects on open areas to provide cover and realistic combat, buildings and ruins provides the only covers, which makes it very obvious. Rocks and trees can also be used but it's usually not really effective and not well placed.
- Despite the fact that teamwork is very important to win the game, majority part of the community are not cooperative nor communicative. But this is not completely their fault, the devs are guilty too, here. More about this will be written on part 4.

3. TL;DR
Great gameplay, pay to win is annoying, challenging shooting system, one of the best WW2 MMOFPS out there with large player base, land vehicles, planes & infantry battle, grinding is almost pointless due to expensive weapons, imperious & immature moderators that are capable to ban you (rare occurance). Point is, if you're not ready to spend money on this game, don't waste your time grinding. If you are really into WW2 MMOFPS, this game is worth trying.

4. Pay to Win analysis & Why so many negative reviews
This is the main reason the community keep bashing Heroes & Generals with bad reviews, completely ignoring the good side of the game and creating a negative-only review, reinforced by the infamous dev's incapability to take criticisms and the squad of immature & imperious mods that bans players who killed them in-game. On the other hand, I am used to these kind of games. I am originally from Indonesia, and Steam wasn't very popular there. I spent years playing crappy online games which is much worse than Heroes and Generals and has worse Pay to Win system before I knew about Steam. And believe me, gaming devs that implement this kind of Pay to Win system will grow in an extremely slow rate, with most of them ending up in bankruptcy. Their revenue might be large but the volume of the financial flow will grow too slow, not growing at all, or even starts dropping where they'll have to cut down the pay to win system, leading to low or even negative profit.

Their main income sources are rich kids, new gamers, impulsive people, WW2 history nerd gamer, and pardon my language, complete idiots. They are the only ones who will spend money on this game and their population is decreasing rapidly with gamers' adaptation to the pay to win system. Gamers can't be so easily fooled to spend money on a pay-to-win game like those early online gamers back in 2000s. Their money-grabbing behavior just won't work in today's gaming community. The biggest flaw of Heroes & Generals' Pay to Win system is their limitation of the main gameplay itself, which is their main power. It is the only WW2 MMOFPS out there that has a large player base and they failed to use that advantage properly.

Creating a pay wall in front of soldier classes, nickname change, weapon mods, land vehicles, and planes is an unbelievably imbecile pay-to-win implementation. Those things are the primary features that builds the main gameplay. Giving massively underpowered tanks to people who doesn't spend money is also a very foolish step. This pay wall prevent the teamwork element from running properly since the core of the game is guarded by a massive pay wall.

If they ever want to repair the reputation and ensure their companies' future, I suggest they completely remove the pay wall that limits the gameplay, lower all prices/increase income from each game to make it worthwile to play, remove durability system/lower the price to repair stuff, and remove the game from Free to Play section. People's price range varies but I personally willing to pay maximum $20 for this quality of game with no pay-to-win system as a prerequisite. If they remove the alpha and make the graphics, animations & textures better, plus adding more new significant features (new nations? new weapons? new planes? new vehicles?), I would definitely willing to pay up to $35 for a copy. Balance the guns and vehicles to prevent frustration on new players. Create a workshop and sell skins on community market just like CS:GO's strategy as an extra income that won't interfere with the gameplay. Add more guns to increase income from skins. Hire mature and professional mods. And many other stuff they could improve. They need to learn that this kind of behavior belongs to developing countries that is still new to online gaming compared to US and EU. For example, they would do well in Indonesia (not for long). Their current course is without question outdated and leads to failure.

reviewText:
Product received for free

Early Access Review

I have over 1000 hours logged playing the actual FPS side of this game, and likely in the realm of 3000 hours of logged in RTS portion since I started playing prior to the game being released on Steam.  I have been a huge supporter of this game 4 years or better.

Any veteran player of this game would describe it as a diamond in the ruff.  The game 'has' huge potential.  Unforuntately, the RETO's lack of direction, lack of foresight, utter contempt for it's player community, and pure arrogance is what is holding this game's potential back.

This game has been steadily going downhill for years.  Each new build sees systems that should help the game improve, but the developers make poor design choices, take forever to fix them (if they fix them at all), and usually introduces changes that the community absolutely does not want.  Being in beta for years, and with over 2 dozen major feature builds (while in beta), is a healthy sign that this game looks like it is going somewhere, but after playing it for a while you will find it is going nowhere and fast.

I really want to continue to support this game, but RETO makes it impossible.  Every build sees increased difficulty of new players to actively integrate into the game and become a long term stable player in the community.  One can no longer meaningfully participate in the war campaign RTS side of the game without serious restrictions.

Waiting times increase in every build.  In match maker quickplay battles you wait in matchmaking queue.  Then you wait to spawn in game.  Then you wait to respawn if you die quickly (likely due to being spawncamped).  In the RTS side of the game, you grind for hours and hours as a new player to earn your first assault team, then you wait in deploy queue for timeframes measured in days.  You then wait for your at to move around which can take an hour.  Then you wait while a battle is prepared, then you wait for the battle to start, then you wait to spawn, then you wait in respawn deploy queue.  Wait wait wait.

Want to play with your friends?  It's better if you have only 2.  Any more and you will be waiting for their battle to end, and not actually getting a chance to play the game.  Wait some more.

My suggestion? Wait until some other competent development team realizes what a great idea the marriage of RTS and FPS is, and then play that one.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I want to like this game, I tried really hard to like this game, but it makes it really hard, if not impossible for that to happen.

Lets start with the basics, the game has a very big pay to win sort of feeling to it, you dont NEED to pay mind you, but the way the game is set up, it puts you at a big disadvantage starting out if you don't and instead try to use the ingame credits that you accrue slowly during normal play.

After that, the maps are huge. Thankfully the developers thought to include bicycles to help you get from point A to point B faster, but thats a whole nother issue I'll get to in a bit. Starting out, the maps seem big, it makes getting around a bit of a pain, but it doesn't seem too bad. You see, your first 3 ranks in the game are spent on 'training maps' or something like that, they are smaller than the average maps, but still pretty damned big. They feel comfortably sized relative to the number of players, although I think they could increase the number of players per side 50% and it would be even better. After your first 3 levels though, you go to campaign maps, and thats where it gets to be painful.

Those maps are several times larger, you NEED bicycles or apcs or cars to get around on them, otherwise you'll never see anything, however the bicycles are harder to come by on those maps, meaning you have to hoof it. Thankfully as players progress through the game they can purchase the ability to spawn cars, apc's, tanks, etc. but in my experience, its possible to end up on a server where nobody on your team has them. These maps are so large that the distance between objectives is several minutes at walking speed. That might sound cool, except at least as far as I can tell, the number of players on these maps is no greater than the smaller ones, I've yet to see more than 18 players per side, while the maps themselves are easily the size of larger 64 v 64 Battlefield style maps, it feels like the 'correct' number of players would be more along the lines of 100 per side on these actually, especially due to the fact that the maps are pretty open, meaning that players can easily spend 20 minutes going through the wilderness not seeing anyone, only to pop up behind the enemy lines and just have a good time shooting them in the back... repeatedly... nonstop. Of course, this is something that SHOULD be in the game, but the ease at which its accomplished, due to the fact that at any given time the majority of players on a team will be between their nearest spawn point and the objective they are trying to capture makes it extremely frustrating and it can and does break your momentum and just lead to a frustrated player base.

Oh, and those bicycles I mentioned? While nice in theory, they have a serious drawback in that you cannot use your weapon while riding and they make you a HUGE target. You would think that it would be an easy fix, get say 75% of the way there on bike, dismount, and hoof it for the last 30 seconds to where you're trying to go... except on these campaign maps your opponent will usually see you almost as soon as you mount the bike, and they will be firing at you, and probably kill you... and if you do manage to get to that magic 75% mark and dismount, well remember how I said that the opposing team will frequently get behind your lines? Yup, they have an uncanny knack for popping out from behind a tree 15 feet behind you and shooting you dead while you're relatively helpless for the brief couple seconds it takes to dismount.

And the other vehicles you can spawn like trucks, apcs, tanks, etc? Those are pretty cool, but again, you have to make an investment to acquire them and be able to use them, something not everyone does, and something which it doesnt seem that the matchmaking service (which is the only real way I've been able to get games... the game does let you pick your battles on the map, but ive yet to be able to get into any when i tried) takes that into account, as i've played on these larger maps where one side was almost entirely devoid of these vehicles, meaning they were forced to walk where bicycles weren't available. In fact, it gets worse, as it doesn't even attempt to balance the number of players with access to things like tanks against eachother. I am writing this, after having just completed a game in which the opposing team had not one, not two, but THREE tanks (mixture of Shermans and Hellcats) against my own teams ZERO, we had nothing larger than a Kubelwagen armed with a machine gun, which is effectively useless against heavy armored vehicles like the ones we were up against.

Theoretically this is counteracted by the fact that players can equip themselves with things like panzerschrecks, bazookas, anti-tank mines, etc. but there are two problems with this - the first is that as far as I know this isn't possible DURING a battle, you have to have your loadout, etc. set up before the battle, the second issue is that access to these weapons is a function of both your rank and how much you're willing to pay. Yes, of course you can use the in-game currency to buy a panzerschreck instead of paying out of pocket, but its not really something you want to spend your credits on, as doing so means that you're not spending money on new rifles or weapons modifications, etc. Beyond that, equipping that panzerschreck occupies an equipment slot, which one im not sure, because I (like most it seems) haven't purchased a panzerschreck, which means - theoretically speaking - that you could end up equipping that weapon and ending up on a map where you have no real targets to use it against (I certainly haven't seen tanks very often, and the lighter vehicles like jeeps are easily handled with small arms).  The developers DID however seemingly have the foresight to provide the spawn areas with panzerfausts (and presumably a LAW type weapon for the allies), however that has yet to materialize as a viable solution in the games I've played. Picking up the panzerfaust means you have to carry the panzerfaust, as in it replaces your rifle, so when you inevitably encounter enemy infantry BEFORE you get close enough to actually be able to get a shot off at the enemy vehicle your options are to fire the panzerfaust at them in the hopes that you kill them, or drop the panzerfaust to pull your rifle back out, you'll often be killed before you can manage that. On top of that, the panzerfaust is rarely a one hit kill unless its one of the lighter vehicles like the jeep, and given that its a single fire weapon, that means that firign at the enemy tank won't kill it or necessarily even neutralize it, just damage it, so unless one of your other teammates managed to pick up a panzerfaust (its often not very easy to find), somehow survive long enough to get into engagement range and fire it off, chances are your opponents will have the tank repaired before you have a second shot.

Which brings me to my next issue with the game, cover. I love that the game requires you to move tactically to be successful, running in the open WILL GET YOU KILLED. Thats a good thing, I think. The problem is that crouching is terribly slow, and for all the open space on these maps, it will take you a REAL long time to get around that way. And dont even get me started on prone, it might make you harder to spot and hit, but it also makes you effectively defenseless, as you move unrealistically slow, and actually turning around while prone is evidently impossible, so if you need to see whats behind you... yeah, you're going to have to stand back up. On top of that, moving tactically is largely useless when your opponents are just as likely to be behind you as they are in front of you. Most of my deaths come from being shot from my side or rear, likewise most of the kills I have come from shooting someone from the side or in the back, even when I'm in a 'head-on-head' engagement. Anyway, thats all the character limit will allow me to say.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Since I’m a huge Battlefield fan and seeing the death of the all-out-warfare behemoth makes me incredibly sad, I’m inclined to find alternatives. In my search, I stumbled upon the beta of Heroes & Generals – WWII FPS-strategy hybrid. It’s developed by Reto-Moto, a team consisting of ex-IO-Interactive founders.

What they have done here with Heroes & Generals is fascinating: they’ve combined two very different games we love to play – an FPS: playing as a soldier on the field and a tabletop wargame: leading the whole war campaign strategy as a commander.

Which leads us to some very interesting territory – metagame in the form of wars, taking weeks until one of the sides (United States or Germany) wins. It’s like eRepublik, in the sense that the FPS battles that players fight directly influence the whole campaign map.

You can look at it as an MMO or just a regular FPS. But before I tell you if it is any good I have to mention few important things about it though.

Heroes & Generals is Free2Play, which means it’s full of unlockables and all sorts of bars that measure your progress. The second warning is that this game is still in development, in fact, it was recently released on Steam Early Access (which means one of the two things – either there are going to be tons of micro patches or no mega patches at all (just kidding)).

How does it work?

The way the whole game is constructed is actually pretty interesting. Let me TRY to explain everything I have managed to grasp so far.

Imagine that the metagame is on a map with control points (CP) and roads in between them. Some control points are factories, that produce machines (tanks, planes, etc.) and cities, that produce ammunition and men.

The goal is for any of the sides to capture as many CPs as possible with assault teams (AT), that are created with men. ATs and supplies can be moved and commanders assign resources to each AT. When two opposing ATs meet in a control point, the matchmaker creates a room and regular soldiers fight in the so called Action Game – the FPS portion of this title.

The layout of main bases and capture points in the FPS map also differ, depending on the meta map. When one of the sides wins the battle, the according side assumes control over the point of interest.

Sounds interesting and at the same time confusing? It absolutely does!

Aufmerksamkeit Soldat!

My biggest interest is in the Action Game which I’ve spent 3 hours in so far.

The general impression I got from spending my time is that Action Game is very much like Red Orchestra (RO) – light realism and not fast paced Team Fortress 2. Depending on the map size and the resources the commander has made available, there are more vehicles in a given mission.

For example there is a hilly forest map where the only vehicles you will encounter are civilian bicycles. It is an adorable scene to watch people ride on this thing, given the fact that two people can get on it, while ringing its cute bell. But you might also fight in a map with light tanks that will shred you into pieces and planes that will drop payloads onto your little head.

One interesting aspect I noticed is the player count in Heroes & Generals – 18vs18. That seems like an odd choice to me, given the fact that most shooters go for 16vs16 or 32vs32.

The gunplay is not the most satisfying I’ve seen, but it’s not bad by any means, for me it’s above average. The gun recoil is actually pretty low, but the bullet spread is not a joke. The equipment you carry in Heroes & Generals compared to your regular $60 shooter is rather limited, here you start only with a rifle and few grenades. Unlocking additional weapons, gadgets and vehicles requires a lot of playing, hence the Free To Play structure of this game.

Usually I don’t like when shooters have 30+ weapons, but the case here is different – there are too few – only handful of rifles and machine guns. I hope they add few more to the rotation as the development goes further.

One thing I noticed that people may dislike is that the player movement can be described as “sluggish” – there is momentum to it, like Miasmata. Another thing that surprised me about it was that in the crouch and lay down positions it’s way slower than other shooters like Red Orchestra and Battlefield – I don’t recommend crawling. There is also sprinting, but it acts like dashing, since you can’t sprint hundreds of meters. Also, jumping is floaty, like on a lower gravity Earth, which I hope gets refined.

As it is in our age, doing all sorts of things on the field in today's FPSs earns you combat badges. Heroes & Generals lets you equip those and have minor buffs, like +7.5% damage to armoured targets when you use the Chauffeur badge for example.

There is also an interesting game mechanic where you can’t get in enemy vehicles, unless you unlock them with holding “E” for some time, depending on the size of the machine you are trying to bust in.

One peculiar feature about the tanks I noticed is that you can get in third person view, but that exposes your characters model for easy shots from the hostile outside world. I think this is an interesting trade off for those who like to be always aware of their surroundings.

Enemy technical spotted!

Because Heroes & Generals is still not baked properly, if you decide to play it now, among the fun you are going to have, you will also be greeted with some frustrating and clearly not finished features.

While most F2P MMOs in engine rendering, server browser and character screens are seemingly in one window, this is not the case with Heroes & Generals. The 3D rendered scenes are done separately from the other features mentioned above, like Battlelog in the newer Battlefield titles. Which results in a relatively smooth Action Game, while the Commander map is working very slow.

Then there is the options menu that can be accessed only in the Action Game, where aren’t that many graphical options to begin with, but good set of sound ones. You can bind your keys, but one thing that bothered me was that I had to hold right mouse button to stay in sights, which I’ve never liked to do in any game.

All of this also means that the server browser/character screens have their own options menu, which makes things a bit confusing.

One of the weakest points of this game is its lobby user interface. The server browser is lackluster, where you can’t see the actual ping values. When I jumped blind into this game I tried to use the queue system – don’t bother. There aren’t that many people playing Heroes & Generals right now, just look for Enter Combat->Find Mission and then try to find a game that has Join Mission on the session overview screen.

The whole unlocking and finding the different customization options can also be a bit confusing at first glance.

Another complaint I have is when a war starts, you have to choose which side you will fight on for the duration of it. Which means that your account will be tied to either US or Germany. After the war ends you can change your faction.

Freundlich Basis voraus

To be honest even when I mention all of the problems Heroes & Generals has, just talking about the game makes me want to play it more. The game might not be the next Battlefield, but it doesn’t necessarily need to be either.

What we have here are some solid foundations, where something really cool can be made and enjoyed by a lot of people. Here is hoping Reto-Moto makes Heroes & Generals even better!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Love this game, while all the whining is on pay-to-win, it isn't really true because you can't pay to get exclusive OP items. Every item can be obtained through game credit, hence it really is a simple equation of you deciding you wanna spend time or money to get the item you want.

i've found it extremely fun simply by the fact that there is no indicators on the enemy and hence, you really have to know what you are doing. Plenty a time, i walked into an enemy prowling down without realising he's there! Additionally, i love being in the middle of a battle where there's infantry, paratroopers. bikes, rovers, tanks and airplanes all in one! Been looking for a game like this and i've finally found it!

I do honestly like this game it has good mechanics and is just a fun time but the main thing that bugs me are these War maches i get into. Most of the time they are completly one sided and usually consist of one team made up of around 18 infianty with no vehicles and the other team with about 12 infanty with vehicles and supported by 5 or so tanks and of course all the tanks have to do is stand still and shoot across a long distance with their cannons and gun down anyone who gets near them and then they win every single time. Some times they underdog teams does manage to get a few tank kills but are soon gunned down by the infanty or another tank. Bazookas, panzershreks, and PTRD's are good to have as an infintryman but cant do much when you only get to have one shot off before you get cut in half by machineguns.
Basically work on game balance, but if you're not playing war mode you will have a fairly balanced experinece.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you're a fan of WW games, then this game will appeal to you, i have no doubts of that. The mechanics are solid and the maps well desinged considering the Domination-esque game mods that i have played so far.  I would recommed this game to anyone who likes First Person Shooters, as it is highly satisfying nailing your target across a foggy expanss where visability through your iron sights is limited.
But that is where the recomendations stop, completely.
Pay To Win is a term i hate, because alot of the time ( in my experience of both console, Xbox 360, PS3 and PS4 and now PC ) it terns out to be true, and i cant help feeling that its no different in this rough diamond of a game. Such a shame the devs have made it so that it takes nearly 5 hours, depending on your skill level, to unlock a sidearm. And even then you have to spend an arm and a leg to buy it with currancy earned via playing the game, or use gold" which is expensive to buy (real money wise) which is just stupid in my opinion
date: as this grind fest makes the game not worth playing.\nIf this were say a £7.99 game or a £9.99 game with no rediculous microtransactions or a reasonable progression system
recommended: it would a feather in the cap of WW2 FPS's availble now."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An honest attempt at a World War II game, we have: Heroes and Generals; but the question stands. Can you compare it favorably to others in the genre?

Personally I think no, with a brief explanation.

This game is rife with server problems such as a single European server which automatically puts the North American and South American players at a disadvantage.

The incessant grind for players to level up and move through the game with weapon modifications, ranks to unlock different classes of the game and low payout for non-premium players.

The lack of a playability for this game. I started playing the game earlier in 2014, having a mediocre time due to the same problems listed before; only to check up on the game with the new Russian inclusion of the game to find the same problems compounded.

And finally the Early Access part of the game; why finish a game that has no end but for the players to grow tired of never ending spawn-killing from tanks, snipers and the rush of Sub machine gunners to capture a base against your default weapon.


All in all, this game is a dissappointing No to the recommended portion. I have played this game with others and it has been only to laugh at how this game could have been great and gripe about it's very clear shortcomings.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

PAY TO WIN
And borderline Pay to Play. You will spend days grinding, carefully mind you, to still get no where. And the upgrades, well, they're not really an upgrade at all. Unless you got plenty of extra money lying around.

I wanna love this game so bad. At it's core it is really good. Runs smooth at max, good visuals, although the sounds are bad in my opinion. But overall a really good game. Minus a few things.

And the Devs have no friggin' idea what constitutes a cheater.
Non-participating, meaning trying to grind your ribbons, which is part of the game the Devs put in, is counted as cheating. Just running around or going prone for a long time means you a cheater.
BUT, a player who camps his/her tank or truck in front of your deployment and kills you every time you leave, apparently is ok with the Dev.

Unbalanced, unfair and down right disturbing.

Massive thumbs down to the Developer. Do not even bother...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Note: I have also played on browser version, so my total playing time is ways more than just my steam hours.

I started playing after the timoshenko update hit and I absolutely loved it. Great gameplay, lots of laughs, premium players have no advantages (except leveling/money bonusses and weapon skins) and the way it worked was good. Reto did a lot to improve the game, they added new guns, nerfed and buffed stuff to make it more fair. The thing i loved about this game was the different weapons for each faction, all with their own characteristics. The grinding part of the game is kinda bad, but when you have grinded long enough you can upgrade your gun. That is also something i loved about this game, since you can mod your guns the way you like them. A big disadvantage about the grinding and modding thing is that people you'll fight against as a beginning player will have better guns, but that is not that bad since its lots of fun to play.

It was huge fun to participate in a battle with tanks, planes, and lots of lil' infantry jimmy's. There was still a lot of work to do, since hits werent always counted and character movement was quite poor. Reto improved that and added lots of stuff to the game in the updates. A little bit to much probably. We have loads of camo to choose from now but we only have a few maps to fight in. They keep adding camo and and unnecessary stuff (like the third german pistol), but it seems like they dont care about adding new maps. In one of the last updates they added more vegetation, but all they did was copy paste the same bush all over the place. After 5 years of early access developing, the graphical part of the game is still very bad.

Something else i dont like about the game is the toxic community who wants reto to nerf everything they get killed with. Thats also because of the different types of players (e.g. tankers want to nerf anti tank stuff, infantry wants to nerf tanks). I used to play all classes and i think it is pretty balanced. Reto did a good job on balancing, allthough the russians are a little bit underpowered and germans a bit overpowered (e.g. MG42(1200 max rpm) and the heavily armored tanks).

Till this Devyatayev" squad update hit i absolutely loved it. Sometimes the battles where a little unbalanced
date: e.g. when the enemys had lots of tanks and your team had none

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've played this game for some time, and after several updates and a reasonably high volume of battles, I feel like I'm familiar with this game at its core, down to the good, the bad and the ugly - and there is a lot of ugly, though whether it outweighs the good is best left to personal discretion. My opinions are as follows:

Pros:
- WWII FPS with a lot of potential.
- Infantry-based gameplay can be quite dynamic, and there are plenty of options to better shape how you play on the battlefield.
- Battles can be quite dynamic, especially with the sheer size of the teams (which can reach over fourty people when lumped together).
- The game performs well, and is generally easy to run at higher settings without sacrificing memory or framerate.

Cons:
- The Devs are more focused on adding new content, as opposed to hearing their community out/fixing problems that are currently detrimental to the flow and feel of the game.
- The graphics are so-so, though the effects can be quite straining on the eyes.
- Assets and high-tier weapons, which have to be unlocked after lengthy grinds, can be quite imbalanced and are often 'spammed' - especially in the assault game mode.
- In spite of the variety available to players as they advance, the new 'squad' system has effectively squashed many of the previously effective means of combatting an overflow of one thing, such as tanks or aircraft, which can make battles quite one-sided.
- Badges, which are used to better augment your soldier/tailor your performance to your style of play, are implemented poorly. Unless you run with veteran membership, there are only a few that will objectively net you the most for the grind involved in picking them up.

After several years of early access and beta status, this game reeks of confusion in its management and a team of developers who have no central idea of what they want the game to be - as well as a poor relationship with the community, who they rarely listen to. When this game is at its best, it can be really, really good fun, especially if you bring a friend or two with you to make things even more interesting. At its worst, it's a grind that can leave you feeling frustrated and unfufilled, especially if you haven't unlocked the best toys to play with.

More often than not, assets have a widely eschewed place on the battlefield. There are some games where tanks and aircraft lend more to the dynamic, and fill a position that better suits the flow of the game (tanks push points/eliminate hostile vehicles, and aircraft battle for air superiority before attempting much the same), while the overwhelming majority seem to lean in favour of overflow.

I cannot tell you how many games I've had to sit through running panzerfausts (the only form of AT that spawns on each of the maps) hoping that I'd be able to deal with tanks while they camp my team out of the spawn; nor how many times I've been bombed trying to rejoin the fight after being knocked out somewhere closer to the front lines; nor can I tell you how many times I've loaded up a vehicle or tank, only to find myself inundated with mines before the admittedly weak spawn protection feature (rendering you invisible to the enemy until a handful of seconds had passed) faded. And with the new squad update, dealing with this has become even harder than before.

Tankers, unless they grind for squad points to load their squad with auxillary seats allowing any of the other branches, are effectively helpless against players who camp spawns/run only AT. With the most recent update, they're also stuck with incredibly long respawn times (I've had up to 400 seconds before I could spawn, drive five feet, and then die to another spawncamper only to repeat the same process again).

Infantry have less of a way to deal with airborne and fighters, as they can no longer load up their own fighters unless they repeat the same process as above, except with fighter seats. The same applies for tanks, assuming no-one on their team is either focused enough or advanced enough to have picked up AT of any form. The panzerfausts I mentioned earlier are only good up to end-tier medium tanks, and even then, only from the sides and rear.

Fighters, admittedly, face the least danger, as nearly all forms of AA are useless (though tankers can fill that role reasonably well if they get a good line of fire.), but they are no less disadvantaged against any number of problems, should they find themselves outnumbered/matched or without targets to shoot at/try to harry.

The gameplay, once you advance far enough, can get quite monotonous. Most players run the 'Heavyset' badge, usually accompanied by some form of SMG (which are usually way, way more accurate than they aught to be. The PPS, as an example, is ludicrously accurate even out to medium range, provided you can see your target) - though there are still a fair number of people who use sniper-rifles, rifles or more varied loadouts. My only serious complaint here is that certain nations have weapons that are innately better than others, and some without any real equal among the other nations' ladder of weapons/arms. The Russians are able to pick up the PTRD anti-tank rifle, while no other nation has a weapon of that caliber at their disposal. Americans have sticky grenades, which face neither the penetration problems of thrown AT grenades against some medium and heavy tanks, and often 'correct' onto whatever you're throwing them at. The Germans have access to MGs that no other nation can reasonably field, though their place is admittedly niche at best. And thus far, reto has only continued to throw new things in while doing nothing to fix any of the above.

I still play this game because I have fun juuuuust enough to keep me hopeful that my experience won't completely sour, but there are times where I leave this game halfway wanting to uninstall it. Your opinions may vary, and I strongly encourage you to figure things out for yourself. Just be aware that your mileage may vary quite a lot.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is a really mixed bag, so it was hard to me to decide whether I recommend it or not.
But now I've made up my mind, I do not.
The game itself is really enjoyable with different maps and career paths to take.
There's a lot to like in this game.
However a lot of these types of games get ruined by their economy or atleast fractions of their economy and H&G is no exception.
The guns are overpriced and overpowered. If someone uses real money to purchase a gun you'll feel it, the game is very much, pay to win.
Free credits are not well balanced, specifically designed to be hard to earn to buy new weapons, so that you'll be more tempted to use your hard earned cash.
You think that if a game was to have hard to earn rewards, it'd take a Planetside 2 approach, and make all guns have strengths, weaknesses and be overall balanced. but they are not. The Thompson for example is the be all end all of submachine guns, I picked one up from an enemy and a quick burst of 3 bullets to the chest was all it took to down an enemy.
however with the Grease Gun, america's starting SMG it took around 20, requiring the full clip if you miss.
The german starting SMG is also stronger than the Grease Gun as well.
There's not a large variety of guns either, which makes me question it a little, considering that I remember a larger array of weaponry in similar WW2 shooters.

The game is fun, refreshing even, however the unfairness of it's economy and weapon tier system really ruin the fun.
Unbalanced weaponry and inconsistent weapons between both factions, leaves something to be desired.
This game would really benefit from leaving it's limitations, creating a third fictional faction to make battles 3 ways, or even adding the ability for 3 way battles which would include weaponry specific to that faction based in that time frame.
This game is in need of a massive overhaul in order to improve player satisfaction and balance between all players, new and long running.

Also, a quick mention for server maintenance, this game is riddled with it, atleast 30% of the time when I want to jump on, there's server maintenance, and this isn't for short periods of time, these are long downtimes, that when the time to be taken is predicted, takes anywhere from 2 to 8 hours, and when the maintenance is unexpected bugfixes or anything along those lines, the game can be done for a whole night, with no time given to players as to when it'll be back up.

My verdict: a good game turned sour by it's online shop.

6/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When the big ban wave rolled a couple months ago, it swept out the cheaters and hackers en masse.  It worked very well.  That's the good news.  The bad news is that 60% of the people playing the game were cheaters, so now you'll sit in queues for ages waiting for a match, unless you want to play the mindless skirmish matches -- which I do not.

It's now ultra-grindy, as well.  Good luck getting to field grade without paying, which effectively cuts you off from the strategic portion of the game -- literally half of the attraction of playing.  (That's the Generals" part...)

This one will be dead in another year.  Don't waste your time."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Most blatant Pay TO Win game ever created.

First off let me clarify. I understand this game is free to play. I also understand the developer needs a source of income to continue updating and dev'ing. I GET THAT. There is a point where the line is crossed and the makers of this game passed that line and kept going.

This game had potential, but as with the current state of PC and Console games, the p2w scale of this game has to be at the top of the list. The devs of this game pretty much have an ATM set up at the front lobby. Its pretty sad and pathetic that this is the route games have gone these days. If I enjoy a game and you can drop 5 bucks on something to get a small upgrade is one thing. But the blatant money grab in this game is shameful.

Why I only may have 20 hours on this game.. I gave it my best attempt to give it a chance. You have to use credits to maintain your weapons, grenades, ammo and such. You have to pay to name your character. You grind your ♥♥♥ off, unlock a ammo type or sight for your weapon and then have to pay to use it. Its ♥♥♥♥ing insanity. Its time the PC community stop letting this ♥♥♥♥ happen. The wallet ♥♥♥♥ is getting out of hand.

Also the grind in this is unreal. You can't play any new maps until you get to level 5. So you gind out he same 3 ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t maps over and over and over and over again. I have played 20 hours in this game and have yet to reach level 5. 20 HOURS TO GET TO LEVEL 5.

The russian side is so overpowered, the germans are 2nd and the US 3rd. Playing against the russians is so frustrating. I give up.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Finally, a WWII first-person shooter that ask the hard questions, like: “What, exactly, is the normalized value of eight M1 Garand rounds and a hand grenade?”, “How do I balance my esprit-de-corps against the operational cost of my grease gun?”, and “Can myself and a friend, riding a bicycle, outpace a 1940’s Ford truck?”

The answers to two out of three of these questions are addressed by a clever twist on a tried-and-true free-to-play mechanic known as “credits”.  The answer to the other question is simply, “Yes”.

Each round players are awarded credits according to their performance relative to everyone else on the server.  Each round credits are deducted a specific amount for every bullet you fired, every grenade you threw, and for “maintenance” of the equipment that you brought into the match.  These are the “Heroes” in “Generals and Heroes”, apparently burdened with the cost of supplying and maintaining their patriotism-waging equipment.

I can only surmise that this must have something to do with the overarching concept that some general, somewhere, has to sign off on requisition forms to get bullets, grenades, and the WWII equivalent of hot pockets into the hands of soldiers every time they want to put boots on the ground.  This mechanic is what puts the “Generals” into the “Heroes and Generals” of this game.  Not really sure how that part works because I like to emphasize the “Free” in “Free to Play”, and putting on a General hat seems to involve either grinding away at this game for a very long time or handing over real life currency.

If you have ever wanted to a play a game where pulling the trigger was preceded by a momentary pause to consider the cost of taking a shot, or enjoy tallying the expenditures of a military campaign down to the level of individual bullets, this is the game for you.

It is otherwise a pretty straightforward WWII first-person-shooter.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

To sum it up: pay to win.

You start off playing training missions, and for the most part is is quite fun. The game's mechanics are not on par with other WW2 shooters out there such as DoD: Source or more importantly Red Orchestra 2, but you're willing to look past that because of the overarching goal to 'win the war' and the fact that the game's progression gives you incentives to keep playing.

Unfortunately it's when you rank up and step out of training missions into the campaign missions where the game comes undone. Whilst it is refreshing to finally see the game as it was meant to be played, that is with multiple goals and not just the domination gametype in the training missions, you'll often be outnumbered or outnumber the enemy team and crush them. Not only that but you'll start playing against people who have spent inordinate amounts of money on ridiculous weapon mods that will one shot you and they'll also take 3x the amount of damage of a normal person due to some insane perk they unlocked via money. Yes you can grind to attain some of these advantages but it is a long and arduous grind, not something the average person could hope to attain. I'm willing to have some iffy balance in a WW2 game seeing as in real life battles are not always fair, but when you get the drop on a guy who is peddling a bike, you put 6 rounds into him and then he jumps off his bike only to one shot kill you it is incredibly frustrating.

Something that I very much get in a RO2 match is the feel of war; bullets whizzing over my head, soldiers writhing in pain, artillery raining down close to me. All these things are just non existent in H&G, half the time you won't even hear the shot that killed you, the audio in general is awful.

Pros:
Progression is definitely there.
You feel like there is an overarching goal to 'win the war'.

Cons:
Wonky mechanics, not as good as other current WW2 shooters on the market.
Pay to win or if you are not fond of that term, pay to advance.
Awful balancing.
No visceral 'war' feeling.

Recommendation: Go buy Red Orchestra 2.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game just can't get my recommendation. I'd leave it at neutral if I could. The game itself is fun. You got vehicles and explosions all about. I enjoy that it does retain some sense of realism to it.
Here's why I'm neutral on it: The best teams to join in when you start off the game is American. If you start off as Soviet Union or Germany though, you will probably not see victories unless the opposing team has way less members than you, or until you reach the point of seeing automatic weapons on your team being used. When you join a match, you'll begin to realize that the Americans have fully automatic weapons and even vehicles with MGs on them. As for the Soviets? Well, we start off with semi automatic rifles and jeeps/trucks that serve no purpose other than transport.
Why is this a problem? A lot of the starting battles take place at close range so the full auto guns have complete advantage over the Soviet Union. The armed vehicles actually suppress and deteriorate any advance made by Soviet Union.

You could say Get skill" but really
date: it wouldn't matter. You can be extremely skilled and yet
recommended: be so limited due to the crappy Soviet loadout. It seems you would actually need to PAY to win as the Soviets. So unless I begin to see the starter battles look less biased towards Americans
hoursPlayed: my opinion won't change."

recommended:

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I was actually playing this game before it came to Steam when it was all done through a browser.... So my timing on the game might be short, but that is because I am a long time player before Steam release.

So I originally got into this game as an alpha before Steam hit, back then the game was starting out and came a long way since then.

Graphics: The graphics are actually quiet good and overal a nice touch on the game with some cool effects and detailing when in battle and not.

Controls: These actually take some getting used too, I found the character control to be slightly annoying but then that could be the kinda sim feel to the game I think, but it does take some time to get used too, so be warned.

Audio: The game is basically WWII sounds and so on, I must say some of the sounds in the game are really good and spot on with detail and worth having it loud.

Now the game and it's features:

Would you say the game is pay to win? Yes, with what I seen in the game it is very easy to buy some of the best stuff and just run around killing stuff quickly.  You also get a few idiots in the game that just mess around in the middle of battle, which is highly annoying but then in the middle of a battle you see a guy on a pushbike riding past a tank, rather amusing and enjoyable.
Even though there that kinda pay to win aspect of the game, you can earn the stuff in the game still as it just takes some more time to get there, so that is annoying but then being a very enjoyable game I cannot really doubt it because the game is very fun and mixed with the graphics which are very detailed I would say, full looking around.... massive plus.

Would I recommend the game? Yes and no, and the only no is the pay to win on the game, but everything else is yes without a doubt.

A free to play WWII shooter, basically an updated BF1942 game with kinda more.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The devs really want to make this game look pretty, with all the fancy screenshots ands artwork and upgrades and currencies and everything. Then you get into the game. I used to play a lot of CoD back in the day, I don't know whether I got so rusty or is it the game. It's just so clunky shooting at things, it just doesn't fell reliable or good for me, it's just really annoying. And I think they know that. Hence the whole currency system. Yeah you're not having fun, but you can earn points and buy better gear, so that should keep you playing.

You get a bad gun at the beginning, and you are supposed to kill stuff exclusively with that gun for FIFTEEN HOURS if you want to get a decent one. But have to play more if you want good upgrades. Correct me if I'm wrong, but the more points you get in game the more currency you are awarded. If you just got out out of the low level incubator, you are pinned against experienced people with tanks snipers etc. I personally didn't like running 3 minutes to the battlefront just to get shot down from who knows where (in CoD that only took like 10 seconds).

My point is, I am really really frustrated by the game. There is no real reason for me to play it. I found playing the game a drag, with the only motivation being getting currency for better guns. You spawn, you run for 2-3 mins and maybe, maybe you kill a few peeps or even make a cap. If you are new and haven't spent money that will be the case. I know, the graphics are good, the models are pretty, it has cars and tanks and planes and on paper it's a really good game model. But I got little actual fun from it. To the devs: I really don't know what would make me rethink, maybe drastically lower grind times I dunno. Sry. My opinion: A pretty looking grindy waste of time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

have folowed development for 2 years (yes the horible browser launcher) and game does not change to any  significant degree. sadly this game is not free to play but free to try becouse you will need to pay if you want to do anything else than run around with a gun as standart inf. this is not a bad thing but tanks are not balanced properly as they dominate. yes as inf you CAN kill it but good luck on open ground with that.

so is this game funs as inf. well it can be however gun play is clunky at best (it got worse from last time i played it on browser). there is bad mouse accel wich makes aiming an absolute pain and no way to turn it of. the attacking team is at a BIG disatvantage becouse the camping side has a good atvantage due to 1 headshot kill mechanics (hard to pull of on moving targets) and how difficult it can be to spot ppl. HOWEVER getting headshots and kills is verry rewarding and there is real tension due to 1 shot kills.

conclusion: the game is verry good in places and at times however it is pay to win becouse everything that isn't standart inf is clearly better to a more or lesser degree. the game has issues balance wise and some smaller ones in other departmends but don't count on any of them being fixed sins there were no noticable changes in my 2 to 3 years of not playing the game. there are better free to play shooters and this game is only free to play in the most strict meaning of the word.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's a fun game, with a nice progression system BUT its hideously imbalanced. Pay to win is everywhere, vehicles are a joke to fight as they can kill you without effort from either 50m or 500m and unless you put a anti-tank weapon in your loadout before you start even searching then GG. The economy in game makes battlefield heros look well made, after grinding for a day I bought a RPG, 5 games later the repair cost for it was the same as the buy price making it utterly unprofitable to use (loosing maybe 3k a match if I wanted to keep using it) stock weapons are a joke with their upgraded variaints a ♥♥♥♥ take whilst I only played germans I picked up enough american grease guns to know it would be quicker to kill a man with actual grease, the tompson however is capable of 720 no scope cross map one shots (only a slight exaggeration). Another example is the bolt action rifle, its useless at first and is so expensive that it is impracticle to buy it without money, each mod which is needed to turn it into a frikkin laser beam capable of oneshotting anything even with a leg shot (not an exaggeration) each then cost the same as the intial purchace. This is only shadowing one major ♥♥♥♥ up of design, the squad set up. If you want to play with your friends and they are a different class than you, then you are not playing with them simple as. To become a tanker or pilot it now costs around 50,000 ingame credits after todays patch, (that's a lot)  you then need to pay to change back to infantry and if you need to do this then you are going to pay another 50k to become a tanker again... The game still needs a lot of work to be fun to play and whilst maybe 1 in 4 matches are actually fun which strangly seem always fight russians, the other 3 ruin the experiance.

also pistols and any top end american weapon are BS OP crap.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Battlefield 1942 Nostalgia Simulator.

Really, the game is a reminder of to what point the industry has come. While BF1942 was a well optimized, balanced and supported game, then Heroes and Generals' potential" that is so often mentioned in these reviews comes from actually cannibalizing the old school WW2 shooter. The controls are similarly floaty (yet still way more awkward)
date: the battle maps are equally large yet fairly linear (but with fewer people on teams to create a real ghost town effect) and the concept centered around combined arms warfare (without the class system that actually enabled infantry to compete with mechanized branches of war).\n\nAnd to make matters worse than the "borrowing" from BF1942 being done ineptly
recommended: it is all coated with a great helping of P2W glazing. Where you could just jump in a plane or pick a sniper class in BF1942 and have the experience guide you to be better and better and eventually a competitive player of your own
hoursPlayed: here you either need to slog through a horrifying grind where you are essentially left at the hands of those people who fate has somehow decreed to own better weapons than you (and be grateful if it's only a high tier SMG instead of a freaking tank)
voteText: or simply those who (for some reason or another) have decided to support the game with their hard-earned cash.\n\nNow
helpfulPercent: I can see why the game piques one's interest. The concept of being a foot soldier commanded by humans high up the food chain is something video games don't really do that often
votesHelpful: but as things stand
votesTotal: for an FPS player
votesFunny: the "Generals" aspect seems foreign and indecipherable as they seem to do little more than imbalance specific scenarios
commentsCount: which
column16: from a strictly FPS point of view
column17: is incredibly infuriating. Maybe I'm just not clever enough to pick up why things happen the way they do
column18: but as a simpleton of a simple soldier
column19: the fact that I'm given a low tier weapon and am expected to die against opposition far better armed than me is immensely unfair. Maybe this is what "Heroes" references - the men of WW2 who were indeed put in hopeless and unfair situations - but I cannot see how such exposure to real tragedies is fun to anyone but the most sadomasochistic roleplayer.\n\nAnd as such
column20: I'm left with slogging through the game
column21: hoping to unlock that amazing sniper rifle I picked up off the ground once and went on a fifteen to nothing killing spree with. But it's way too long of a stride and offers little on the way - and considering how the battles are empty and chaotic (20 players per team seems to be a good haul - on maps that force you to ride bikes to control points only to be scythed down by better-equipped players it means that you will almost never be allowed to "pick your own battles"
column22: if you catch my drift) it doesn't really strike me as being worth it. Unfortunately these core issues do not look like they'll be fixed any time soon. I can handle floaty and imprecise controls when the concept gives me enjoyment
column23: but there is so much infuriating me about every aspect of the game that long playing sessions are out of the question. As such I'm left with quick spurts of 30-40 minutes of gameplay
column24: which obviously means that unlocking any of the high tier weaponry is a pipe dream at best.\n\nSo is this game worth contributing towards? Honest to god
column25: if you have any money to spare
column26: organize some kind of revival of BF1942 instead. If you play this for free
column27: consider that you won't get any long term enjoyment of it. Value the initial few hours skirmishes and move on. But all in all
column28: this one is just a major let down."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Upon starting this game for the first time I was greeted with a familiar site. What at first appeared to be a quick attempt to throw together dated graphics, and a pay-to-win profit model cloaked in a well used FPS genre, turned out to offer more than my initial reaction gave credit for. While that reaction is harsh, the game does contain dated graphics(eg. 2010), and a profit model that allows paying players to progress more quickly. What Heroes & Generals also offers is solid gameplay, progressive customization, and well balanced maps, all painted in a coat of FPS nostalgia.

With most free-to-play titles the first thing people criticize is the monetezation features, and this was one of the first areas I investigated. I'm glad to see that Heroes & Generals does a great job of avoiding the pay-to-win pitfall. By making all equipment available for both in game credits, and Gold purchased with real funds, H&G developers made it possible for people, paying or not, to access the same gear, albeit at different times. Monetization features allow players to purchase pre-trained soldiers, increase Credits/Warfunds earned in battles, unlock/purchase equipment/skins, purchase Assault Squads, and unlock 1 extra badge/equipment slots.

Overall Heroes & Generals is a balanced experience, and a game I will continue to play. While at points the game may seem unfair due to people having better equipment than you, it is actually a nice dose of realism, as in war you are not always evenly matched technologically. This game is still in Early Access, so expect minor bugs and glitches, but at this point I've encountered very few. This game is at the perfect point to start playing and becoming active in the community. For the price I highly suggest taking some time to play this game, and develop your own opinions, and if you have suggestions don't hesitate to voice them on the forums, because that's the whole point of the Early Access system.

I am huge fan of WW2 games, but this one is kind of disgrace. I played nearly 70h but i managed to get only 6th rank. Weapon prices are ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ joke (you need to play several hours to get some weapon). Lack of realism and bugs are biggest cancer of this game. PzI and Konigstiger needs the same amount of missiles to destroy them, only difference is armor. You can't destroy tankette with AA gun, when you'll jump to deep water from 4-5m you'll get nearly killed, heaviest tank can be easily destroyed by single mine, distance calibration sometimes doesn't work. Players are mostly ♥♥♥♥ing campers, they are camping at spawn and hunting you down with single shot of their OP rifles. If devs won't repair this game it will be one of the worst WW2 MMOs ever. Better buy RO.

EDIT:
After few updates it is a little better, but still I can't recommend this game. After several months they have added just one map. Every type of terrain has the same map. Battle of Berlin looks the same as battle of Kuybyshev. Devs, get your lazy asses to work.
